solr_doc_hash.mms_name: Undesirable elements/Canarsie [High School], New School University, N.Y., 2003-03
title: Undesirable elements/Canarsie [High School], New School University, N.Y., 2003-03
Ping Chong archive: Moving image materials
title_sort: Undesirable elements/Canarsie [High School], New School University, N.Y., 2003-03
Ping Chong archive: Moving image materials
name: Chong, Ping
Chong, Ping
Ping Chong & Company
New School University
Global Kids Annual Youth Conference (2003 : Canarsie, N.Y.)
subject: Monologues -- Performances
Cultural pluralism -- Drama
Performance art
Youth -- Political activity -- New York (State)
abstract: This creation is an on-going series of community-specific works by Ping Chong exploring the effects of history, culture and ethnicity on the lives of individuals in a community. The piece is made through a collaborative workshop process involving Ping Chong and a group of people who vary in many ways but share the common experience of having been born in one culture and now being part of another. Each production is made in a specific host community with local participants testifying to their real lives and experiences.
note: Global Kids presents ; [conceived and directed by Ping Chong].
No credits on tape, production information gathered from original VHS cassette label and accompanying materials.
Performed by unidentified Canarsie [High School, N.Y.] students.
Videotaped during Global Kids Annual Youth Conference live performance at New School University, N.Y., Mar. 2003.
The processing of the Ping Chong audio-visual materials was made possible, in part, through the generous assistance of the Leon Levy Foundation.
Gift; Ping Chong & Company; 2009. NN-PD
Forms part of: Ping Chong archive. Moving image materials.

Performance art
Youth -- Political activity -- New York (State) -- New York
abstract: Documentary on the production of the on-going series of community-specific works by Ping Chong exploring the effects of history, culture and ethnicity on the lives of individuals in a community. The piece is made through a collaborative workshop process involving Ping Chong and a group of people who vary in many ways but share the common experience of having been born in one culture and now being part of another. Each production is made in a specific host community with local participants testifying to their real lives and experiences. Includes interviews with the performers and excerpts from the show.
note: [conceived and directed by Ping Chong].
No credits on tape, production information gathered from original VHS cassette label and accompanying materials.
Video, Dahna Abourahme ; director, Emerald Trinket Monsod.
Undesirable elements crew: Anna Montes, Tianna Villafane. Special guest, Patrick Ssenjovu
Undesirable elements cast: Meighan Ackon, Marisol Agosto, Rachard Badal, Shomari Chinnery, Nakitta Feliciano, Colin Frederickson, Lailoni Narvaes.
Videotaped as a part of the DreamYard arts-in-education program in 2001, N.Y.
The processing of the Ping Chong audio-visual materials was made possible, in part, through the generous assistance of the Leon Levy Foundation.
Gift; Ping Chong & Company; 2009. NN-PD
Forms part of: Ping Chong archive. Moving image materials.

abstract: This creation is an on-going series of community-specific works by Ping Chong exploring the effects of history, culture and ethnicity on the lives of individuals in a community. The piece is made through a collaborative workshop process involving Ping Chong and a group of people who vary in many ways but share the common experience of having been born in one culture and now being part of another. Each production is made in a specific host community with local participants testifying to their real lives and experiences.
note: [conceived and directed by Ping Chong].
No credits on tape, production information gathered from original VHS cassette label.
Director, Emerald Trinket Monsod.
Videotaped at the Julia De Burgos Latino Cultural Center, East Harlem, N.Y., as a part of the DreamYard arts-in-education program, May 30, 2001, N.Y.
The processing of the Ping Chong audio-visual materials was made possible, in part, through the generous assistance of the Leon Levy Foundation.

The piece is made through a collaborative workshop process involving Ping Chong and a group of people who vary in many ways but share the common experience of having been born in one culture and now being part of another. Each production is made in a specific host community with local participants testifying to their real lives and experiences.</abstract><note type="statement of responsibility" ID="note_0">[conceived and directed by Ping Chong].</note><note ID="note_1">No credits on tape, production information gathered from original VHS cassette label.</note><note type="creation/production credits" ID="note_2">Director, Emerald Trinket Monsod.</note><note type="venue" ID="note_3">Videotaped at the Julia De Burgos Latino Cultural Center, East Harlem, N.Y., as a part of the DreamYard arts-in-education program, May 30, 2001, N.Y.</note><note type="funding" ID="note_4">The processing of the Ping Chong audio-visual materials was made possible, in part, through the generous assistance of the Leon Levy Foundation.</note><note type="acquisition" ID="note_5">Gift; Ping Chong & Company; 2009. Video art
abstract: The production is a prismatic exploration of Korean history from the 16th to the 20th century, focusing particularly on relations with Japan and the United States. The play is the fourth part of Ping Chong's East-West series, which deals with the history between Asian cultures and the West and also includes Deshima (Japan), Chinoiserie (China), and After sorrow (Vietnam). Three actors narrate and comment on the history and culture of Korea, using both historical fact and legend as a basis for telling the story.
note: Institute on the Arts and Civic Dialogue, in association with Ping Chong and Company presents ; conceived and directed by Ping Chong.
No credits on tape. All credits and rehearsal information gathered from original VHS cassette label and program notes for the same performance held on the same date.

Dongil Lee, dramaturgy ; Watoku Ueno, set design ; Brian Hallas, sound design ; Hitoshi Yoshiki, technical director ; Jan Hartley, graphic design ; Courtney Golden, stage manager ; John Malinowski, lighting design ; [Stefani Mar, costume design?].
Esther K. Chae, C.S. Lee, Shin Young Lee.
Recorded in dress rehearsal possibly at the Chinese Culture Center, Boston, Mass., July 31, 1999.
The processing of the Ping Chong audio-visual materials was made possible, in part, through the generous assistance of the Leon Levy Foundation.
Gift; Ping Chong & Company; 2009. NN-PD
Forms part of: Ping Chong archive. Moving image materials.

name: Chong, Ping
Chong, Ping
Ping Chong & Company
subject: Theater rehearsals -- United States
Immigrants -- United States -- Drama
Chinese -- United States -- Drama
China -- Relations -- Western countries -- Drama
East and West -- Drama
Video art
abstract: A rehearsal of the multimedia performance piece portraying through song, dance, and spoken text critical moments in Chinese-Western relations, focusing mainly on the history of Chinese immigrants and their descendants in the United States, especially the discrimination and mistreatment they endured. Interspersed are personal anecdotes told by Ping Chong, himself a Chinese-American. Part two of a trilogy dealing with East-West encounters, comprised also of Deshima and After sorrow.
note: conceived and directed by Ping Chong.
The processing of the Ping Chong audio-visual materials was made possible, in part, through the generous assistance of the Leon Levy Foundation.
Gift; Ping Chong & Company; 2009. NN-PD
Forms part of: the Ping Chong archive. Moving image materials.

name: Chong, Ping
AM Singapore (Television program : Singapore)
subject: Chong, Ping -- Interviews
Chong, Ping
Theatrical producers and directors -- United States -- Interviews
Video art
abstract: [Jane Ong] interviews Ping Chong, American contemporary theater director, choreographer, video and installation artist. Chong discusses his production of the play Deshima, a documentary collage of the history of the West and Japan. The interview precedes the show that played the next day [June. 15, 1996] at the Victoria Theatre, Singapore.
note: Broadcast on the television program AM Singapore, June 14, 1996.
The processing of the Ping Chong audio-visual materials was made possible, in part, through the generous assistance of the Leon Levy Foundation.
Gift; Ping Chong & Company; 2009. NN-PD
Forms part of: the Ping Chong archive. Moving image materials.

note: On The Boards presents Ping Chong & The Fiji Theatre Co. ; created and directed by Ping Chong.
No credits on tape, production information gathered from original VHS cassette label and from the program.
"Dedicated to Jean Claude Ribes" -- Program.

Film directed by Ping Chong ; David Gearey, cinematographer & editor ; music composed for the film by Meredith Monk ; lab sequence in film lit by Tobey Sanford ; Ping Chong & Paul Krajniak, art directors ; Paul Krajniak, designer in chief ; Blu, lighting designer ; Don Voisine, technical director ; Phil Lee & Howard Kaufman, sound engineers ; Kim Druce & Louise Smith, costume design.

Ishmael Houston-Jones, Kara Westerman, Louise Steinman, Ciel Werts, Louise Smith, Rob List, performers ; Michael Duffy, Ishmael Houston-Jones, Phil Lee, narrators ; Rob List, Ciel Werst, Ping Chong, performers in the film.
Videotaped at the Washington Hall Performance Gallery, Seattle, Washington, Jan. 22, 1983.
The processing of the Ping Chong audio-visual materials was made possible, in part, through the generous assistance of the Leon Levy Foundation.
Gift; Ping Chong & Company; 2009. NN-PD

abstract: Dance/theater work. The performance footage (ca. 68 min.) is followed by ca. 37 min. of repetitions of excerpts from the work, some in close shot.
note: presented by Ping Chong and Company ; [created] by Ping Chong in collaboration with the designers and the performers.
Assistant director, Virlana Tkacz ; sound, Brian Hallas ; set and costumes, Matthew Yokobosky ; lighting, Howard Thies.
Karen Booth, John Fleming, Dan Froot, Larry Malvern, and Louise Smith.
Videotaped in performance at La Mama E.T.C., New York, on December 1, 1989, by Character Generators/Video, cameraperson, Michael Schwartz.

name: Chong, Ping
subject: Chong, Ping -- Interviews
Theatrical producers and directors -- United States -- Interviews
Video art
abstract: An unidentified host interviews Ping Chong, American contemporary theater director, choreographer, and video and installation artist. Chong discusses his production of the play Deshima, a documentary collage of the history of the West and Japan. The interview includes excerpts from the show produced at the Sterrenbos Studio, Utrecht, Holland, May 19, [1990].
note: Recorded in Holland, [1990].
The processing of the Ping Chong audio-visual materials was made possible, in part, through the generous assistance of the Leon Levy Foundation.
Gift; Ping Chong & Company; 2009. NN-PD
Spoken in English, titles in Dutch.
Forms part of: the Ping Chong archive. Moving image materials.

subject: Arts -- Singapore
Art, Singaporean
Chong, Ping -- Interviews
Theatrical producers and directors -- United States -- Interviews
Video art
Television series
abstract: Vivian Wang presents the production of the play Deshima as a part of the arts festival held in Singapore, summer [1996]. Includes excerpts from the interview with Ping Chong, Asian-American contemporary theater director, choreographer, video and installation artist, and fragments of the show that he conceived and directed. Chong discusses the production, a documentary collage of the history of the West and Japan, that played at the Victoria Theatre, Singapore, [summer 1996] .
note: produced by Yarra Films for Singapore TV 12 ; presented by Vivian Wang.
Broadcast on the arts program Artitude, TV 12 channel, Singapore, [1996].
The processing of the Ping Chong audio-visual materials was made possible, in part, through the generous assistance of the Leon Levy Foundation.
Gift; Ping Chong & Company; 2009. NN-PD
Forms part of: the Ping Chong archive. Moving image materials.
